reporting-org.narrative: Promundo is a global leader in promoting gender justice and preventing violence by engaging men and boys in partnership with women and girls. We believe that working with men and boys to transform harmful gender norms and unequal power dynamics is a critical part of the solution to achieve gender equality. For the empowerment of women and girls to continue advancing, men and boys must see themselves as allies in the process. Men and boys also benefit when harmful norms are challenged. Our research, programs, and advocacy efforts show that promoting healthy masculinity (or positive notions of “what it means to be a man”) and femininity (or “what is means to be a woman”) leads to improvements in men’s own lives, and in the lives of women and girls.

title.narrative: Prevention+ Rwanda

description.narrative: Prevention+ aims to address gender inequality by promoting masculinities based on equality, non-violence and care-giving, and by focusing on boys and men, and girls and women, as agents of change. The long-term objectives of this five-year program are to contribute to a gender just society which is free of gender-based violence (GBV). Prevention+ aims to transform social norms that drive GBV, and contribute to related changes in legislation, policies and practices of governments and other service providers. Rutgers, Promundo, and Sonke Gender Justice, along with local partners, will work with institutions and male and female adolescents and adults across Indonesia, Pakistan, Uganda, Rwanda and selected MENA countries. Women’s rights organizations are essential partners of this program to support activities and advocate for change. The MenEngage Alliance will further promote Prevention+ objectives internationally through its network and policy advocacy. The program is evidence-based; it has been developed on the basis of research findings that show that well-designed gender-transformative programs with both sexes of different age groups are highly effective in order to underpin the positive transformation of rigid gender norms, and contribute to a society free of GBV. Prevention+ is funded by the Government of the Netherlands.

title.narrative: Result Area 1: OUTPUT: (Young) men and women have access to information and education concerning GBV, parenting, and gender justice

Result Area 1: OUTCOME: (Young) men and women have more gender just attitudes and behavior
1.2 Improved communication skills within % of the participating couples

comment.narrative: Interviews with Parents' Evening Dialogue facilitators, participants, and key stakeholders indicated that the PED meetings and the skills and information learned there have increased communication between women and men and their understanding of its importance - both between partners and within the family - to ensure healthy, peaceful relations.

title.narrative: 1.1 % of participating (young) men and women have more positive attitudes, including acceptance of positive masculinities (including equitable, non-violent, caregiving) and of women’s political and economic participation
1.3 % participating (young) men and women who do not believe intimate partner violence is acceptable

comment.narrative: Young people participating in the Y4C clubs reported positive shifts in attitudes accepting of intimate partner violence after participating in the training provided by RWAMREC. The percent of youth who agreed with attitudes justifying IPV reduced by almost half between pre- and post-tests. Specifically, the percent of respondents who believed that violence between partners is a private matter and that others should not interfere reduced overall from 14 percent to 7 percent between pre- and post-tests (statistically significant). The percent of respondents who agreed with the statement that a woman should tolerate violence in order to keep the family together decreased from 9 to 5 percent between pre- and post-tests. Across six such hypothetical scenarios, the percent of respondents who justified VAW for at least one scenario reduced from 71% in the pre-test to 50% in the post-test (statistically significant).

title.narrative: 1.6 % of (young) men and women report positive changes towards more equitable decision-making patterns (e.g. on household economics)

comment.narrative:
Young people participating in the Y4C clubs reported substantial improvements in attitudes related to equitable household decision-making after participating, with fewer respondents supportive of men's dominance in household decisions. Between pre- and post-tests: respondents agreeing with the statement, "the man in the household should always have the final word on household decisions", reduced from 48% to 20% (statistically significant); agreement with the statement, "a woman must never question her husband's decisions", also decreased from 25% to 12% (statistically significant); and agreement with the statement, "the man should make final decisions about money in the household" also reduced from 37% to 17% (statistically significant).
In interviews, women and men who participated in the Parents Evening Dialogues reported greater support for and implementation of more equitable decision-making within the family as a result of the participating in the PED meetings. Specifically, some women and men reported that the PED meetings/sessions had changed men's attitudes towards financial decisions, allowing for greater involvement of women in household decisions.

title.narrative: 1.5 Reduced levels of intimate partner violence among % of participants

comment.narrative: Parents Evening Dialogue Committee members (including PED Presidents, Secretaries, and village chiefs) who facilitate the PEDs, as well as key stakeholders who handle cases of intimate partner and family violence (e.g. Police, Rwanda Investigation Bureau) in Karongi report that RWAMREC's training and integration of a gender-transformative approach within the PEDs has contributed to reducing intimate partner and family violence in villages in Karongi district.

title.narrative: Result Area 3: OUTCOME: Improved quality of GBV programming and services provided to (young) women and men within the public and CSO sector
3.3 Increased comfort and skills in trained government and CSO staff in working with (young) men to prevent GBV

comment.narrative: Trainings conducted by RWAMREC for the teachers and head-teachers, Parents Evening Dialogue (PED) committee members and local officials contributed to greater comfort and skills for engaging men and boys in GBV prevention after the trainings, however participants self-reported high rates of comfort and skills prior to the trainings. Specifically, we see that 97% of teachers and head-teachers (96 males; 100 females) reported feeling they had the necessary skills to engage men and boys in GBV prevention after the training (compared to 82% pre-training). Most participants reported feeling comfortable, but there was an increase in those reporting they felt "very comfortable" engaging men and boys in their community in GBV prevention (from 50% to 78% among males; from 68% to 85% among females. Among PED committee members, most trainees already felt they had the necessary skills and knowledge to work with boys in GBV prevention, however there was a slight improvement between the pre- and post-tests (from 92% to 96%). Among local officials, all participants in both pre- and post-tests felt comfortable talking to men and boys in their community in GBV prevention, but the percentage who said they were "very comfortable" increased from 79% to 88%. In interviews, several PED committee members expressed their pride in facilitating the sessions using the curriculum and skills they learned and highlighted the importance of the training and resources enabling them to promote men's engagement in the PED sessions and to assist families in their communities.

title.narrative: 3.1 More favourable attitudes towards gender equity among % of trained government and CSO staff

comment.narrative: Stakeholders trained by Prevention+ reported more equitable gender attitudes after being trained - based on pre- and post-tests using the Gender Equitable Men (GEM) scores, a measure of gender equitable attitudes on a scale from 0 to 3, with higher scores indicating more equitable attitudes, as well as interviews. Trained teachers and head-teachers' average GEM scores increased from 2.02 to 2.47 between pre- and post-tests (statistically significant); trained Parents Evening Dialogue (PED) committee members' average GEM scores increased from 1.26 to 1.97 (statistically significant); participating local officials' GEM scores improved slightly from 2.17 to 2.36. Interviews with trained media and CSO representatives indicated positive shifts in attitudes towards gender equity. Qualitative responses suggest there was a widespread increase in interest in covering gender issues with more seriousness, especially domestic violence. Participants also shared how they intended to use the power of the media to shift gender-inequitable narratives and challenge stereotypes. Interviews with trained PED committee members highlighted how the training they received led to changes in their own attitudes (and behaviour) related to gender equity.

title.narrative: 3.2 More favourable attitudes towards engaging (young) men in GBV prevention among trained government and CSO staff

comment.narrative: There was already widespread consensus that engaging (young) men in GBV prevention was an important priority among most of the key stakeholders targeted by Prevention+ , although mild improvement in attitudes was reported in post-tests. Among teachers and head-teachers involved with Y4C clubs, 99 percent reported that engaging young men in GBV prevention was important and a priority for them in the pre-test, which increased to 100 percent in the post-test. Participating parents evening dialogue (PED) committee members, 97 percent felt in the pre-test that it was a priority for them to engage young men in GBV prevention, and this percentage moved to 98 percent in the post-test. Among participating local officials, over 96 percent of respondents overall felt that engaging young men and boys in GBV prevention was important and that it was a priority for them in their work. In interviews, the PED committee members highlighted how the gender-transformative, male engagement curriculum and training from RWAMREC has enabled them to effectively engage men in the PED sessions.

title.narrative: RESULT AREA 3: OUTCOME: More CSOs and relevant public sectors have institutionalized gender transformative approaches.
3.5 Targeted institutions have developed and/or implemented more favourable policies, budgets, protocols or guidelines
3.6 Targeted institutions/ CSOs integrate gender transformative approaches in services offered
Result Area 2: OUTCOME: Increased supportive norms to prevent GBV and promote gender justice
2.1 Increased positive notions of manhood (equitable, non-violent and caring) among (young) men and women in the targeted communities

comment.narrative:
Interviews and focus group discussions with students, Youth4Change club participants and facilitators, indicate that the clubs had an impact on transforming attitudes, norms and practices related to gender equality and positive notions of manhood within the broader school communities including: a greater involvement of boys/young men in cleaning and unpaid care work within the school (and at home); greater confidence and representation of young women in student leadership and more equitable relationships and collaboration between male and female students; and greater openness about menstruation among girls and greater care and understanding about menstruation on the part of boys.
Interviews and focus group discussions with Parents Evening Dialogue committee members, participants and students, indicate that the PEDs have also led to changes in positive notions of manhood (equitable, non-violent, caring) within their communities, particularly: the increased engagement of men in the PED sessions; more equitable and harmonious relationships between women and men, less conflict and violence, and greater involvement of men in household tasks and caregiving among some families; greater sharing of domestic work among women and men.

title.narrative: 2.2 Positive change within the targeted communities intervening in GBV cases and/or supporting GBV survivors

comment.narrative:
Prevention+ has contributed to a positive shift in community members - male and female - intervening or responding to GBV cases and providing support to GBV survivors through a) the integration of a gender-transformative, male engagement approach within the Parents Evening Dialogues (in 435 villages) district-wide and b) through the implementation of Youth4Change clubs in schools district-wide.
Interviews and focus groups discussions with key participants, facilitators, and stakeholders highlighted multiple ways in which the PEDs themselves and the committee members have become important resources for addressing GBV in the community - both within and outside of the PED sessions, including: a) PED committee members and the PED sessions becoming an important source of advice and counsel to families who are living in conflict and women experiencing violence (who seek out the PED committee members for support), with individuals and couples actively seeking out the PED meetings as an important space in which to seek support, advice and counsel from the PED committee members and community at large; b) PED committee members (and participants) identifying families in the community who need their support and organize home visits to provide advice, support, and referral to services (as required); c) Individual PED participants also cited what they learned in the PED sessions as motivating them to reach out to others in their family or community whom were living in conflict/with violence.
Interviews with Youth4Change club members, facilitators, and stakeholders indicate several ways the clubs have contributed to GBV prevention and response in the broader community. Youth 4 Change Club members were described as actively intervening and supporting survivors of GBV by talking to their parents and reaching out to adult family members and neighbours in the community (sometimes together with the teachers facilitating the clubs) to help prevent and respond to violence. Club members were also described as doing household visits to discuss with students' parents. Club members were also active in organizing outreach and awareness raising on gender equality and GBV prevention through community-wide events such as Umuganda (monthly community service) and Itorero (a nationwide cultural training for young people).
Key stakeholders highlighted the important linkages and synergy between the PED committees and the Y4C clubs as contributing to a greater awareness of and ability to respond to violence in the community, and capacity to support GBV survivors.
